title: 114_hr3515
content: The Act may be cited as the "Dismemberment Abortion Ban Act of 2015". It enforces a ban on dismemberment abortions. The "Dismemberment Abortion Ban Act of 2015" amends Chapter 74 of title 18, United States Code, by prohibiting physicians from performing dismemberment abortions, with exceptions for cases where the mother's life is endangered. This ban does not limit abortions for other reasons, such as rape or incest, if performed using a different method. The "Dismemberment Abortion Ban Act of 2015" prohibits physicians from performing dismemberment abortions, with exceptions for cases where the mother's life is endangered. Civil remedies are available for women or parents of minors who have undergone an abortion in violation of the ban. Appropriate relief includes verifiable money damages. The "Dismemberment Abortion Ban Act of 2015" allows for civil remedies in cases of prohibited abortions, including money damages, statutory damages, and punitive damages. Attorney's fees may be awarded to prevailing parties, and frivolous suits may result in fees for the defendant. No damages are awarded against women except in specific circumstances. The "Dismemberment Abortion Ban Act of 2015" prohibits certain abortions and allows for civil remedies, including damages and attorney's fees. Women who undergo a dismemberment abortion are immune from prosecution under this section. The "Dismemberment Abortion Ban Act of 2015" prohibits dismemberment abortions, defined as knowingly dismembering a living unborn child one piece at a time or intact but crushed from the uterus. This act allows for civil remedies and immunity from prosecution for women undergoing such abortions. The "Dismemberment Abortion Ban Act of 2015" prohibits dismemberment abortions, which involve slicing, crushing, or grasping a portion of the unborn child's body to cut, rip, or crush it. The act excludes abortions using suction to dismember the body unless other methods are used to cause the unborn child's death first. The terms "minor" and "physician" are defined in the act. The "Dismemberment Abortion Ban Act of 2015" prohibits dismemberment abortions, with exceptions for certain methods. It defines terms like "minor" and "physician" and specifies that only authorized individuals can perform abortions. The term "unborn child" is defined as a human organism from fertilization until birth. The "Dismemberment Abortion Ban Act of 2015" prohibits dismemberment abortions and amends chapter headings in title 18, United States Code to replace "Partial-birth abortions" with "Abortions".
